questions.text: A 27-year-old lady presented to OPD with a complaint of pain and redness in her breast with fever. On clinical examination, a 5 x 4 cm area of redness was noted in the breast with ipsilateral axillary lymph node enlargement. What should be the preferred management in this lady? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antibiotics and breast support

 

The clinical presentation of pain, redness, fever, and a 5 x 4 cm area of redness with axillary lymph node enlargement is indicative of mastitis. Mastitis is an inflammation of the breast tissue that is often associated with infection. It is common in breastfeeding women but can also occur in non-lactating women. The typical management for mastitis includes antibiotics to treat the infection and breast support to reduce discomfort.

 

  • Antibiotics: These are essential to treat the bacterial infection causing the mastitis.
  • Breast support: Proper support can help relieve pain and reduce swelling.

 

If there were additional signs such as swelling, fluctuation, high-grade fever with chills, or ultrasound findings showing fluid collection, the diagnosis could be an abscess, which would require a different treatment approach involving aspiration or drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mammography: This is not a first-line investigation or treatment for mastitis. Mammography is typically used for screening and diagnostic purposes in breast cancer and other breast pathologies.

 

Option B. Incision and drainage: This is the treatment for a breast abscess, not uncomplicated mastitis. There is no indication of abscess formation in the given scenario.

 

Option C. Hot compresses and conservative treatment: While hot compresses can provide some symptomatic relief, they are not a substitute for antibiotics in the treatment of an infection like mastitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for mastitis includes antibiotics to address the infection and breast support to alleviate discomfort. Recognize the symptoms of mastitis and differentiate it from a breast abscess, which requires a different management approach.

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is due to defect in which of the following cell?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Type 2 pneumocytes

 

One of the most characteristic findings in respiratory distress syndrome is failure of the respiratory epithelium to secrete adequate quantities of surfactant, a substance normally secreted into the alveoli that decreases the surface tension of the alveolar fluid, therefore allowing the alveoli to open easily during inspiration.

 

The surfactant-secreting cells are type II alveolar epithelial cells.

 

Production of the surfactant begins by week 20-24. It appears in the amniotic fluid between 28 and 32 weeks of gestation. Mature levels of the pulmonary surfactant are present usually after 35 weeks of gestation.

 

Antenatal corticosteroids are given to increase production of surfactant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1 pneumocytes: Incorrect because although Type 1 pneumocytes cover a large surface area of the alveoli and are involved in the gas exchange process, they do not produce surfactant. The defect in Type 1 pneumocytes generally leads to issues with the structural integrity of the alveolar walls, not surfactant deficiency.

 

Option C. Alveolar capillary endothelial cells: Incorrect as these cells line the alveolar capillaries and are involved in the blood-air barrier for gas exchange. Defects in these cells can lead to issues like pulmonary edema but are not directly related to surfactant production or respiratory distress syndrome due to surfactant deficiency.

 

Option D. Bronchial mucosal epithelial cells: Incorrect because these cells line the bronchial passages and are primarily involved in mucous production and the removal of particulates and pathogens from inhaled air. They are not involved in surfactant production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Respiratory distress syndrome, especially in premature infants, is commonly due to insufficient surfactant production by Type 2 pneumocytes. This deficiency impedes the lungs' ability to expand properly, leading to respiratory distress. Management often includes the administration of exogenous surfactant and supportive care to enhance lung function until the infant's own cells can produce adequate surfactant.

choices.text: Oral hairy Leukoplakia

questions.text: An immunocompromised patient presents with the following lesion on the lateral aspect of the tongue as shown in the image below. This white membrane was not scrapeable with a gauze piece. What is the diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral Hairy Leucoplakia

 

Option A:

 

Oral Hairy Leukoplakia:

 

  • This condition is characterized by a white, corrugated, "hairy" plaque typically found on the lateral borders of the tongue.
  • It is commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals, especially those with HIV.
  • The white membrane is not scrapeable, which helps to distinguish it from candidiasis.
  • The presence of this lesion in an immunocompromised patient that is non-scrapeable strongly indicates Oral Hairy Leukoplakia, which is associated with Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lichen Planus:

 

  • This condition usually presents as white, lace-like patterns (Wickham's striae) as shown in the image below, on the buccal mucosa, tongue, and other oral mucosa.

 

 

  • It can sometimes have erosive, painful areas, but it does not have the "hairy" appearance typical of Oral Hairy Leukoplakia.

 

Option C. Lichen Sclerosus:

 

  • This is a chronic condition that typically affects the anogenital area, not the oral mucosa.

 

 

  • It is characterized by white patches that can lead to scarring, but it does not occur on the tongue.

 

Option D. Candidiasis:

 

  • Also known as oral thrush, candidiasis presents with white patches that typically can be scraped off to reveal a red, bleeding surface underneath. The fact that the lesion in the image is not scrapeable makes candidiasis less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diagnose Oral Hairy Leukoplakia by its characteristic non-scrapeable, white, hairy appearance on the lateral aspect of the tongue, especially in immunocompromised patients.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Page no 25.33

questions.text: A lesion involving Brodmann area 22 is most likely to result in which of the following deficits? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Receptive aphasia

 

Broadmann’s area 22 corresponds to Wernicke’s area, which is primarily involved in language comprehension. A lesion in this area leads to receptive aphasia, also known as sensory or Wernicke’s aphasia. In receptive aphasia, patients have difficulty understanding spoken language, and their speech may be fluent but lacks meaning or coherence. They can produce words but often speak in nonsensical phrases or sentences that are difficult to understand, indicating a disruption in the processing of language comprehension.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Poor repetition of language: This is associated with conduction aphasia, which occurs due to a lesion in the arcuate fasciculus that connects Broca's and Wernicke's areas. It is characterized by an inability to repeat words or phrases accurately.

 

Option C. Expressive aphasia: This is also known as Broca’s aphasia, resulting from a lesion in Broadmann’s areas 44 and 45. Patients with expressive aphasia have difficulty producing speech, characterized by slow, halting, and effortful speech, but their comprehension remains intact.

 

Option D. Poor naming: Poor naming is typically observed in anomic aphasia, which occurs when the connection between language processing centers is disrupted, but it is not specific to a lesion in Broadmann’s area 22.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in Broadmann’s area 22, known as Wernicke’s area, leads to receptive aphasia, characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech and impaired comprehension.

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the chest x-ray?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cannonball metastases

 

Explanation

 

The chest x-ray shows multiple round, well-defined nodules distributed throughout the lung fields. These nodules are characteristic of cannonball metastases, which are metastatic lesions typically arising from primary cancers such as renal cell carcinoma, choriocarcinoma, or other malignancies that spread hematogenously to the lungs.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Septic emboli: These typically present with multiple small nodules with a predilection for the lung periphery and often cavitate.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis: Commonly presents with apical lesions, cavitary lesions, or a miliary pattern, not with multiple well-defined round nodules.

 

Option D. Lung abscess: Appears as a localized area of consolidation with a possible air-fluid level indicating cavitation.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Cannonball metastases present as multiple round, well-defined nodules scattered throughout the lung fields on chest x-ray, indicative of metastatic spread.

questions.text: Intermittent dose of Parathyroid hormone causes risk of:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteosarcoma

 

  • Intermittent doses of parathyroid hormone (PTH), specifically recombinant human PTH (teriparatide), are used in the treatment of osteoporosis and are associated with several risks and benefits.
  • Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that has been associated with PTH therapy, but this risk is primarily a concern with long-term continuous exposure rather than intermittent dosing.
  • Mechanism: 
    • Long-term continuous PTH exposure has been shown to increase the risk of osteosarcoma in studies.
    • This is due to PTH's effects on bone remodeling and the potential stimulation of abnormal bone cell proliferation.
  • Teriparatide (intermittent PTH) is used for osteoporosis and involves daily injections of 20mcg for a limited period (usually up to 2 years).
  • Clinical trials and long-term studies have not shown a definitive increase in osteosarcoma risk with this intermittent therapy, but caution is advised as osteosarcoma is a rare complication of intermittent PTH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subtrochanteric Atypical Fracture: Subtrochanteric atypical fractures are a known risk associated with long-term bisphosphonate therapy, not intermittent PTH therapy. Bisphosphonates work by inhibiting bone resorption, which can lead to the accumulation of micro-damage in bones. Over time, this may result in atypical femoral fractures, including subtrochanteric fractures, often with minimal trauma.

 

Option C. Net Loss of Bone Mass: Net loss of bone mass is not a typical outcome of intermittent PTH therapy. Intermittent PTH therapy generally leads to an increase in bone mass and improves bone density, especially when used in conjunction with other osteoporosis treatments. PTH stimulates osteoblast activity, which increases bone formation.

 

Option D. Osteonecrosis of Jaw: Osteonecrosis of the jaw is a condition primarily associated with long-term use of bisphosphonates and other anti-resorptive therapies, not with intermittent PTH therapy. Osteonecrosis of the jaw is a severe condition where the jawbone becomes necrotic due to impaired blood supply, often linked to the suppression of bone resorption. This risk is notably higher with intravenous bisphosphonates and is associated with dental procedures or trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteosarcoma have indicated a potential risk with continuous and intermittent PTH administration, though it is rarely seen complication of intermittent PTH therapy.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents for a routine antenatal checkup at 18 weeks of gestation. On abdominal examination, the uterine size was found to correspond to 16 weeks of gestation. On US, oligohydramnios was found. Which of the following is a likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Renal agenesis

 

  • Early onset oligohydramnios can be due to renal anomalies like
    • B/l renal agenesis
    • B/l dysplastic kidneys
    • B/l Autosomal recessive infantile polycystic kidney disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fetal anemia: Severe fetal anemia also can cause hydrops and polyhydramnios like in Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome and Rh iso-immunization

 

Option C. Barter syndrome and option D. Anencephaly cause polyhydramnios

 

Educational Objective

 

Early onset oligohydramnios can be due to renal anomalies like bilateral renal agenesis, bilateral dysplastic kidneys, or bilateral autosomal recessive infantile polycystic kidney disease.

 

Ref: Page no 352, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is an adverse effect associated with the long-term use of intermittent teriparatide for the treatment of osteoporosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone (PTH) used as an anabolic (bone-building) agent in the treatment of osteoporosis. It is administered via daily subcutaneous injections. While effective in increasing bone mass and reducing fracture risk, the long-term use of teriparatide has been associated with certain risks.

 

Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that has been linked to the long-term use of teriparatide in animal studies. Specifically, when used for more than two years, there is evidence from these studies suggesting an increased risk of developing osteosarcoma. This potential risk has led to a restriction on the duration of teriparatide therapy to a maximum of two years.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteonecrosis of the jaw bone: This condition is a known adverse effect of bisphosphonates, not teriparatide. Bisphosphonates can lead to decreased blood flow to the jawbone, causing osteonecrosis, especially following dental procedures.

 

Option C. Subtrochanteric fracture (atypical femoral fracture): This type of fracture is also associated with long-term use of bisphosphonates, rather than teriparatide. Bisphosphonates may alter bone remodeling, leading to atypical fractures.

 

Option D. Loss of bone mass: Teriparatide is an anabolic agent that actually increases bone mass. Bisphosphonates also prevent bone mass loss by inhibiting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption. Thus, loss of bone mass is not associated with either teriparatide or bisphosphonates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The long-term use of teriparatide is associated with an increased risk of osteosarcoma, which is why its use is limited to a maximum of two years.

questions.text: After cataract surgery, a patient developed vision problems. OCT finding is shown below. This is associated with which syndrome? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Irvine-Gass syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Irvine-Gass syndrome, is a well-known complication in which cystoid macular edema (CME occurs 4 to 6 weeks after cataract surgery. It is characterized by the development of cystoid spaces in the macula, which appear as hyporeflective spaces on Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT).

 

This syndrome is commonly associated with:

 

  • Post-cataract surgery patients, particularly those with pre-existing conditions like diabetes or uveitis or glaucoma patients on PG analogues.
  • Inflammatory mediators such as prostaglandins and cytokines are released post-surgery, leading to increased vascular permeability and leakage of fluid into the macular layers.
  • Fluorescein angiography (FFA) typically shows a petalloid pattern of hyperfluorescence due to leakage from perifoveal capillaries.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central Serous Retinopathy (CSR):

 

  • CSR is characterized by serous detachment of the neurosensory retina at the macula due to increased choroidal permeability.
  • OCT shows serous elevation of the retina without cystic spaces, unlike the cystoid spaces in CME.
  • FFA typically shows an inkblot or smokestack pattern.

 

 

Option B. Elschnig Pearls:

 

  • These are seen in cases of posterior capsular opacification (PCO), which can occur months to years after cataract surgery.
  • This condition is seen on the posterior capsule of the lens bag and not on Retina
  • Patients complain of gradual, painless vision deterioration, unlike the acute onset of CME.

 

Option D. Posner-Schlossman Syndrome:

 

  • Also known as glaucomatocyclitic crisis, it is an inflammatory condition that presents with elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) and mild anterior uveitis.
  • It does not cause cystoid macular edema (CME) or changes seen in Irvine-Gass syndrome.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Irvine-Gass syndrome (cystoid macular edema) is a complication of cataract surgery that presents 4 to 6 weeks postoperatively. It is best diagnosed using OCT and treated with NSAIDs or steroids.

questions.text: Which component of the HIV genome is necessary for the virus to enter the host cell membrane? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GP120

 

GP120 is a glycoprotein on the HIV envelope that binds to the CD4 receptors on host cells. This binding is crucial for the initial attachment of the virus to the host cell, facilitating the subsequent steps that lead to viral entry. GP120 interacts specifically with the CD4 receptor, which is predominantly found on the surface of T-helper cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CCR5: CCR5 is a co-receptor on the host cell surface that HIV uses in conjunction with the CD4 receptor to enter the cell. However, it is not a component of the HIV genome but rather a part of the host cell.

 

Option C. GP41: GP41 is another glycoprotein found on the HIV envelope that assists in the fusion of the viral membrane with the host cell membrane after GP120 has bound to the CD4 receptor. It facilitates the entry of the viral core into the host cell cytoplasm.

 

Option D. CXCR4: CXCR4 is another co-receptor used by HIV to enter host cells, particularly in later stages of infection. Like CCR5, it is a part of the host cell and not a component of the viral genome.

 

Educational Objective:


GP120, a glycoprotein on the HIV envelope, is necessary for binding to CD4 receptors on host cells, facilitating viral entry.

choices.text: Almost never seen in heart with normal morphology
IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control
DC Cardioversion is required in all cases
Discrepancy in HR and PR is a clinically reliable criteria for diagnosis

questions.text: A 38-year-old man collapsed and was brought to the emergency. ECG was taken and a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation (AF) was made. Which of the following is true? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control

 

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm without distinct P waves on ECG, which confirms the diagnosis. Each of the provided options needs to be evaluated for accuracy.

 

IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control. This is the correct statement. IV Digoxin is used for rate control in AF, particularly in patients with heart failure.

 

If the patient is stable and not in acute heart failure, beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers like verapamil or diltiazem are preferred.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Almost never seen in heart with normal morphology: This statement is incorrect. Atrial fibrillation can occur in morphologically normal hearts. Studies indicate that 15-35% of AF cases can be seen in individuals with structurally normal hearts, although it is more common in those with conditions such as heart failure or left atrial enlargement.

 

Option C. DC Cardioversion is required in all cases: This statement is incorrect. DC cardioversion is reserved for unstable patients or for rhythm control in selected chronic cases. It is not required for all AF cases.

 

Option D. Discrepancy in HR and PR is a clinically reliable criteria for diagnosis: This statement is incorrect. While a pulse deficit (difference between heart rate and pulse rate) can suggest AF, it is not a reliable diagnostic criterion as it can be observed in other conditions such as frequent ventricular premature contractions, cardiac tamponade, and severe heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IV Digoxin can be effectively used for ventricular rate control in patients with atrial fibrillation, especially in those with heart failure.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions prolactin level is highest?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 24 hours after delivery

 

Explanation

 

Among the given options, the prolactin level is highest 24 hours after delivery.

 

This hormone is secreted by the mother’s anterior pituitary gland, and its concentration in her blood rises steadily from the fifth week of pregnancy until birth of the baby, at which time it has risen to 10 to 20 times the normal nonpregnant level.

 

  • 24 Hours After Delivery: Following childbirth, prolactin levels are significantly elevated to facilitate breastfeeding. These levels are particularly high immediately postpartum as the body prepares to produce milk to feed the newborn. This is the period when prolactin levels are typically at their highest among the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 24 hours after ovulation: Although hormonal changes related to the menstrual cycle do affect prolactin levels, these changes are moderate and do not typically reach the peak levels seen postpartum. The role of prolactin around ovulation is less pronounced compared to its surge after delivery, where it is critical for initiating and sustaining lactation.

 

Option C. NREM Sleep: Prolactin levels naturally rise during sleep, especially during the deeper stages of NREM sleep, due to reduced dopamine activity, which normally inhibits prolactin secretion. Despite this increase, the levels achieved during sleep are usually not as high as those observed after childbirth, where prolactin plays a direct and significant role in breastfeeding.

 

Option D. After running for 1 hour: Physical activities and stress can lead to an increase in prolactin levels as part of the body's response to physiological stress or exertion. However, these increases are generally transient and significantly lower than the sustained high levels required for lactation post-delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Other factors which leads to high prolactin levels (hyperprolactinemia) in the body are:

 

During sleep, the hypothalamus releases dopamine, which inhibits the secretion of jectiveprolactin. As the night progresses and sleep deepens, dopamine levels decrease, leading to a decrease in the inhibition of prolactin release. Consequently, prolactin levels rise, reaching their peak in the early morning hours.

 

Prolactinoma: The most common cause of hyperprolactinemia is a noncancerous tumour of the pituitary gland called a prolactinoma.

 

Medications: Certain medications can increase prolactin levels. These include antipsychotic (such as risperidone and haloperidol), antidepressants, anti-nausea drugs (such as metoclopramide), and some high blood pressure medications.

 

Hypothyroidism: Underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism) can disrupt the normal balance of hormones in the body, including prolactin regulation.

 

Chronic Kidney Disease: Kidney dysfunction or chronic kidney disease can lead to hyperprolactinemia. Impaired kidney function affects the clearance of prolactin from the blood, leading to elevated levels.

 

Stress and Emotional Factors: Extreme stress, emotional trauma, or intense physical activity can temporarily raise prolactin levels.

 

Pregnancy and Breastfeeding: During pregnancy, prolactin levels increase to prepare the breasts for milk production. After childbirth, prolactin levels remain elevated to stimulate and maintain breastfeeding.

choices.text: Start Antihypertensives and emergency LSCS
Start Antihypertensives and ARM

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 30 weeks presents with painful bleeding PV, reduced fetal movement, increased uterine tone, and absent FHR. BP is 166/98 mmHg, and the cervix is 6cm dilated, 70% effaced with intact membranes. What is the next best step? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start Antihypertensives and ARM

 

Explanation:

 

Given the high BP and symptoms suggesting placental issues, starting antihypertensives addresses the hypertension, and artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) is indicated to advance labor, especially in a context where continuing pregnancy may pose risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency LSCS: An emergency LSCS without addressing hypertension could be risky.

 

Option B. Start Antihypertensives and emergency LSCS: While emergency surgery is critical, managing BP first is essential.

 

Option D. Tocolysis: Tocolysis is contraindicated in hypertensive disorders and fetal distress.

 

Educational objective:

 

In cases of hypertensive crisis with placental issues, managing maternal BP is crucial before procedures like ARM to safely advance labor.

questions.text: A victim of road traffic accident (RTA) presents with fracture of hand with hypothenar atrophy. Nerve involved in him is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulnar nerve

 

  • In the hand, the ulnar nerve gives motor innervation to the hypothenar (palmaris brevis, abductor digiti minimi, flexor digiti minimi, opponens digiti minimi) and the thenar (adductor pollicis, deep head of flexor pollicis brevis) muscles. 
  • Also, it supplies the palmar and dorsal interossei and medial 2 lumbricals.
  • The ulnar nerve is most susceptible to injury at the elbow and the wrist, resulting in motor and sensory loss.
  • Mechanisms of injury include trauma like motor vehicle accident; nerve impingement; lacerations at the wrist; and Guyon’s canal cyst.
  • A motor vehicle accident resulting in a fracture of the metacarpal or phalanges can lead to injury of the ulnar nerve.
  • This is indicated by the atrophy of the hypothenar muscles, leading to flattening of the hypothenar eminence. 
  • Other clinical features of ulnar nerve injury include:
    • Loss of hypothenar eminence
    • Loss of adduction of thumb
    • Loss of abduction of fingers
    • Clawing of 4th and 5th digits

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial nerve: The radial nerve supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm and hand. Injury to this nerve would typically result in wrist drop due to loss of extensor muscle function, not hypothenar atrophy. 

 

Option C. Musculocutaneous nerve: The musculocutaneous nerve supplies the biceps, brachialis, and coracobrachialis muscles in the upper arm. Its involvement would affect arm flexion and not the hypothenar muscles.

 

Option D. Median nerve: The median nerve supplies the thenar eminence and the first two lumbricals. Injury to this nerve would result in issues with thumb opposition and grip, but not hypothenar atrophy.

 

Additional Information: 

 

  • Flexor pollicis brevis superficial head is supplied by median nerve and deep head is supplied by ulnar nerve.
  • The first and second lumbricals are supplied by the median nerve.
  • The third and fourth lumbricals are supplied by the ulnar nerve.
  • When the lumbricals are paralyzed, they can result in a deformity known as a "claw hand."
  • Ulnar or median nerve injury can lead to a deformity known as "claw hand."
  • Among these, ulnar nerve palsy is more commonly associated with claw hand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypothenar atrophy is a clinical sign of ulnar nerve injury.

questions.text: Which of the following elicits maximum pain on injection? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Propofol

 

  • Propofol is notorious for causing pain upon injection.
  • The pain can be severe and is often described as a burning sensation.
  • Various techniques and adjuncts, like mixing with lidocaine or injecting into larger veins, have been recommended to minimize the pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ketamine: While ketamine can sometimes cause a burning sensation upon injection, it's not typically described as the most painful among anesthetic agents. However, when not combined with other medications, it can cause some discomfort upon injection.

 

Option C. Etomidate: Etomidate can cause pain on injection, but the pain is generally less severe compared to propofol.

 

Option D. Thiopentone: Thiopentone can cause some pain upon injection, but it's generally less painful than propofol. However, it can cause tissue necrosis if it is inadvertently injected outside of the vein (extravasation).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propofol is known to cause maximum pain on injection, often described as a severe burning sensation.

questions.text: Which artery is used for AV shunting with the great saphenous vein for hemodialysis and is present behind the medial malleolus and 2.5 cm in front of the tendon calcaneus? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior tibial artery

 

The posterior tibial artery is located behind the medial malleolus and is commonly used in arteriovenous (AV) shunting with the great saphenous vein for hemodialysis access. This artery runs in the posterior compartment of the leg and is palpable behind the medial malleolus, approximately 2.5 cm anterior to the tendon calcaneus (Achilles tendon). It is a reliable location for vascular access because of its relatively superficial position and ease of palpation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peroneal artery: The peroneal artery is located in the lateral compartment of the leg and does not course near the medial malleolus, making it unsuitable for the AV shunting procedure described in the question.

 

Option B. Anterior tibial artery: The anterior tibial artery is located on the anterior aspect of the leg and passes between the medial and lateral malleoli, where it is palpable in front of the ankle joint. It is not positioned behind the medial malleolus, hence it is not the correct answer.

 

Option C. Dorsalis pedis artery: The dorsalis pedis artery is palpable on the dorsum of the foot near the navicular bone or intermediate cuneiform, far from the medial malleolus and tendon calcaneus. Therefore, it is not used for AV shunting as described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior tibial artery is the artery located behind the medial malleolus and is commonly used for AV shunting with the great saphenous vein in procedures like hemodialysis access due to its superficial location and ease of access.

questions.text: A patient, who consumed a large number of TCA pills during a depressive episode, presented with altered sensorium, hypotension, and wide QRS complexes on ECG. What is the next best step in treatment? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NAHCO3

 

A patient presenting with altered sensorium, hypotension, and wide QRS complexes on ECG following an overdose of tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) requires immediate treatment to address the cardiotoxic effects of the overdose. The best next step in this scenario is the administration of intravenous Sodium Bicarbonate (NAHCO3). Sodium Bicarbonate is used to treat the sodium channel blockade caused by TCAs, which is responsible for the wide QRS complexes. It works by alkalinizing the blood, which helps to mitigate the cardiotoxic effects of TCAs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DC Cardioversion: This is generally used for unstable patients with life-threatening arrhythmias. In the case of TCA overdose, the priority is to treat the underlying cause of the arrhythmia (the sodium channel blockade), which is more effectively addressed with sodium bicarbonate.

 

Option B. Start antiarrhythmic drug: The use of antiarrhythmic drugs may be risky in the setting of TCA overdose, as these medications can exacerbate the cardiotoxic effects of TCAs.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect because there is a clear and specific treatment indicated for this scenario, which is the administration of Sodium Bicarbonate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 644.

choices.text: Phosphatidyl serine

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is due to the deficiency of? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dipalmitoyl Phosphatidylcholine

 

Explanation

 

  • Respiratory distress syndrome is due to the deficiency of dipalmitoyl-phosphatidyl-choline (DPPC) /dipalmitoyl lecithin. It is the major pulmonary surfactant (surfactant is a surface-active agent, secreted by type II alveolar epithelial cells) It is a complex mixture of several phospholipids, proteins, and ions.
  • The most important components are the phospholipid dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine, surfactant apoproteins, and calcium ions.
  • The surfactant decreases the surface tension in the alveoli 2- to 10-fold, which normally plays a major role in preventing alveolar collapse.
  • However, in a number of conditions, such as in hyaline membrane disease (also called respiratory distress syndrome), which often occurs in newborn premature babies, the quantity of surfactant secreted by the alveoli is so greatly depressed that the surface tension of the alveolar fluid becomes several times normal. This causes a serious tendency for the lungs of these babies to collapse or to become filled with fluid.
  • Clinical relevance - Test to assess fetal lung maturity is L/S ratio –lecithin/sphingomyelin ratio. A ratio of ≥ 2 is considered normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphatidyl serine: Incorrect. While phosphatidyl serine is a component of cell membranes and plays roles in signaling, it is not a major component of pulmonary surfactant and is not specifically linked to respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Option C. Phosphatidylethanolamine: Incorrect. Similar to phosphatidyl serine, phosphatidylethanolamine is a component of cell membranes and is involved in cellular processes but does not play a direct role in reducing alveolar surface tension or preventing respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Option D. Phosphatidylinositol: Incorrect. Phosphatidylinositol is involved in cellular signaling pathways and membrane structure but is not a significant component of pulmonary surfactant related to respiratory function or the pathology of respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (DPPC) is crucial for reducing surface tension in the alveoli, preventing their collapse, and is the primary component deficient in respiratory distress syndrome, particularly in premature infants. This deficiency underscores the importance of surfactant therapy in the management of this condition.

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer presented with retro-orbital pain, conjunctival suffusion, night fever and chills, calf tenderness, cervical lymphadenopathy, hypokalemia, and joint pain. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

 

Leptospirosis is the Ans.  because the patient's presentation of symptoms, particularly conjunctival suffusion (redness of the conjunctiva), is more characteristic of Leptospirosis than the other conditions listed. This condition is caused by the Leptospira bacteria, which can lead to symptoms like retro-orbital pain, night fevers, chills, calf tenderness, and hypokalemia, all seen in this patient.

 

The key differentiator in this case is conjunctival suffusion, which is commonly observed in Leptospirosis and is not a typical feature of Dengue or other listed conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaria: Malaria usually presents with high fevers, chills, sweats, and headache but does not typically cause conjunctival suffusion or calf tenderness. Additionally, hypokalemia is not a common feature of Malaria.

 

Option C. Filariasis: Filariasis is characterized by lymphatic dysfunction and can cause lymphedema or elephantiasis, but it does not present with retro-orbital pain, conjunctival suffusion, or the other acute symptoms described in the patient.

 

Option D. Dengue: Dengue can present with similar symptoms such as retro-orbital pain, fever, and joint pain, making it a close differential. However, conjunctival suffusion is not a characteristic feature of Dengue, which helps to distinguish it from Leptospirosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conjunctival suffusion is a distinguishing symptom of Leptospirosis and is not commonly seen in Dengue or other similar infectious conditions.

questions.text: What is the vector for the condition diagnosed by the image shown below? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sandfly

 

The image shown is of the Leishman-Donovan bodies whose presence are diagnostic of Kala Azar. The vector of Kala Azar is a sandfly.

 

Leishman-Donovan bodies are amastigotes with a double dot appearance containing a nucleus and small rodlike kinetoplast. They are present inside the macrophage.

 

The sandfly serves as the vector for Leishmania parasites. When a sandfly bites a human, it can transmit the parasites which then proliferate within the host's macrophages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anopheles mosquito: Incorrect, as this mosquito is the vector for malaria, not Kala Azar.

 

Option B. Ixodes Tick: Incorrect, this tick is a vector for diseases like Lyme disease and not for Kala Azar.

 

Option D. Tsetse fly: Incorrect, as Tsetse flies transmit trypanosomes that cause sleeping sickness, not Leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The presence of Leishman-Donovan bodies inside macrophages is indicative of Kala Azar, a severe form of leishmaniasis transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies. Effective prevention and control are critical in endemic regions to reduce the transmission and impact of this disease.

questions.text: A patient with dermatitis herpetiformis presented with chronic diarrhea. What is the likely cause of diarrhea? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Celiac disease

 

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic skin condition characterized by intensely itchy and blistering skin lesions. It is strongly associated with celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten. In celiac disease, exposure to gluten leads to an immune response that damages the lining of the small intestine, resulting in malabsorption and chronic diarrhea.

 

Key points:

 

  • Dermatitis herpetiformis: This condition involves IgA deposits in the tips of the dermal papillae, as seen on skin biopsy. It is a specific marker for celiac disease.
  • Celiac disease: Caused by gluten hypersensitivity, it leads to intestinal inflammation, villous atrophy, and malabsorption, which in turn causes chronic diarrhea.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ulcerative colitis: This is an inflammatory bowel disease affecting the colon and rectum, leading to symptoms like diarrhea and abdominal pain. It is not associated with dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Option B. Whipple’s disease: This rare bacterial infection affects multiple systems, including the intestines, causing malabsorption and diarrhea. It does not have a connection with dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Option D. Crohn’s disease: Another type of inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, causing chronic diarrhea and abdominal pain. It is not related to dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a skin manifestation of celiac disease, and the presence of chronic diarrhea in such a patient is indicative of celiac disease due to gluten hypersensitivity.

choices.text: Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus
Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly with altered echotexture

questions.text: A 12-year girl is brought to the OPD by her mother. She is concerned that she is shorter than her peers. On examination there is ptosis on the right side, shield like chest and a webbed neck. On evaluation, which of the following is the most definitive finding? (NEET PG 2021 )
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus

 

Explanation:

 

Turner Syndrome:

 

  • Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder affecting females, characterized by the absence of all or part of one X chromosome (45,XO).
  • It presents with several distinct clinical features.

 

Clinical Features of Turner Syndrome:

 

  • Short stature: Typically shorter than peers, often the first noticeable symptom.
  • Primary amenorrhea: Due to streak gonads (non-functioning ovaries).
  • Shield-like chest: Broad chest with widely spaced nipples.
  • Webbed neck: Excess skin folds running from the tops of the shoulders to the sides of the neck.
  • Ptosis: Drooping of the upper eyelid, can be unilateral or bilateral.
  • Cardiac defects: Commonly coarctation of the aorta, though ventricular septal defects (VSD) can also occur but are less common.
  • Renal anomalies: Such as horseshoe kidney or a single kidney.
  • Other features: Low-set ears, high-arched palate, arms that turn outward at the elbows, narrow and turned-up fingernails and toenails, low hairline at the back of the head, receding or small lower jaw.

 

Ultrasound Findings:

 

  • The presence of streak ovaries (underdeveloped ovaries) and a small uterus are typical findings in Turner syndrome, leading to primary amenorrhea and infertility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ECHO shows VSD: While Turner syndrome can involve congenital heart defects, the most common cardiac anomalies are coarctation of the aorta and bicuspid aortic valve, not ventricular septal defect (VSD).

 

Option C. Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly with altered echotexture: This is not typically associated with Turner syndrome. Hepatomegaly might suggest liver disease or metabolic disorders, which are not characteristic of Turner syndrome.

 

Option D. Ultrasound showing single kidney: Renal anomalies can occur in Turner syndrome, such as a horseshoe kidney or a single kidney, but the primary findings expected include streak ovaries and a small uterus which are more specific for Turner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45,XO genotype, primary amenorrhea, short stature, and distinctive physical features such as a webbed neck and shield-like chest. Ultrasound typically shows streak ovaries and a small uterus.

 

Ref: Page no 411, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: Identify the source of trauma in the image below. (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bullet

 

The image shows a circular hole with beveling on the outer table of the skull, which is characteristic of a bullet wound. Beveling of the outer table indicates an exit wound, while beveling of the inner table would indicate an entry wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scissor: Incorrect. Scissor injuries typically produce irregular, non-circular wounds with sharp edges, not the circular hole seen in the image.

 

Option B. Rod: Incorrect. Injuries from a rod would usually result in linear or irregular wounds, depending on the shape and force of impact, not a circular hole.

 

Option C. Axe: Incorrect. An axe would cause a large, irregular, and typically more extensive laceration with sharp, defined edges, not a circular hole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A circular hole with beveling on the outer table of the skull is indicative of a bullet wound, specifically an exit wound.

questions.text: Which hormone increases during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GH

 

Growth Hormone (GH) is unique in that it increases during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep. GH plays a crucial role in growth, metabolism, and overall bodily repair and regeneration. During deep sleep, especially during slow-wave sleep, GH secretion peaks. This is vital for tissue growth and repair.

 

Stress and starvation also trigger the release of GH, which helps in mobilizing fat stores for energy and preserving muscle mass, among other functions. These adaptive responses are crucial for survival during periods of physical or emotional stress and food scarcity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucocorticoids:  These hormones, which include cortisol, increase in response to stress and starvation. However, their levels typically decrease during deep sleep and peak in the early morning hours.

 

Option C. Cortisol:  A specific glucocorticoid that increases in response to stress and starvation, but like other glucocorticoids, its levels decrease during deep sleep and peak early in the morning.

 

Option D. Prolactin:  This hormone can increase in response to stress and has a role in metabolism and immune regulation, but it does not have the same peak during deep sleep as GH does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth Hormone (GH) is the hormone that increases during periods of stress, starvation, and especially deep sleep, distinguishing it from other hormones that typically decrease during deep sleep.

choices.text: Pain and temperature loss in the same side
Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side
Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side
Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side

questions.text: Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes which of the following?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side

 

Explanation

 

Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side.

 

The first order neurons carry sensory information regarding touch, proprioception or vibration from the peripheral nerves to the medulla oblongata by two different pathways 

 

  • Signals from the upper limb (T6 and above) – travel in the fasciculus cuneatus (the lateral part of the dorsal column). They then synapse in the nucleus cuneatus of the medulla oblongata.
  • Signals from the lower limb (below T6) – travel in the fasciculus gracilis (the medial part of the dorsal column). They then synapse in the nucleus gracilis of the medulla oblongata.

 

The second order neuron begin in the cuneate nucleus or gracilis. The fibres receive the information from the preceding neuron, and delivers it to the third order neuron in the thalamus. Within the medulla oblongata, these fibres decussate (cross to the other side of the CNS). They then travel in the contralateral medial lemniscus to reach the thalamus.

 

Lastly, the third order neuron transmit the sensory signals from the thalamus to the ipsilateral primary sensory cortex of the brain. They ascend from the ventral posterolateral nucleus of the thalamus, travel through the internal capsule and terminate at the sensory cortex.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pain and temperature loss in the same side: Incorrect, as the medial lemniscus does not primarily carry pain and temperature sensations; these are transmitted by the spinothalamic tract.

 

Option B. Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side: Incorrect for the same reason as above.

 

Option C. Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side: Incorrect because the crossing of fibers in the medulla means that a lesion in the medial lemniscus at the pons affects the opposite side of the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of the pons causes loss of tactile sense and proprioception on the opposite side of the body due to the decussation (crossing over) of second-order neurons in the medulla, which then ascend contralaterally in the medial lemniscus to the brain.

questions.text: Identify the type of epiphysis marked in the given image: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pressure epiphysis

 

Pressure epiphysis is the part of the bone that bear weight or pressure during movement and are located at the ends of long bones. In the image, the tibia and fibula clearly show the ends where pressure is applied during articulation and weight-bearing, marking these regions as pressure epiphyses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Traction epiphysis: Incorrect. Traction epiphyses are involved with ligament or tendon attachment points, such as the trochanters of the femur (like greater and lesser trochanters). These do not bear direct weight.

 

Option C. Aberrant epiphysis: Incorrect. Aberrant epiphyses are usually abnormal and occur in locations where epiphyses are not typically present, like the head of the first metacarpal​. They are not typically found at major weight-bearing joints.

 

Option D. Atavistic epiphysis: Incorrect. Atavistic epiphyses are evolutionary remnants that were previously separate bones in ancestral species but are fused now, such as the coracoid process of the scapula​. They are not related to weight-bearing functions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Apoptotic bodies comprise of: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytoplasm + nuclear fragment + organelle

 

Apoptotic bodies are formed during the process of apoptosis, or programmed cell death. Apoptosis involves the activation of caspase enzymes, endonucleases, and proteases, leading to the fragmentation of the dying cell. These cellular fragments, known as apoptotic bodies, contain components of the cell, including cytoplasm, nuclear fragments, and organelles. The presence of these components within the apoptotic bodies is a key characteristic of the apoptotic process.

 

 

 

 

TUNEL Staining (Mouse liver showing an apoptotic cell stained with TUNEL)

Apoptotic body is looks like a dense, eosinophilic structure,  the presence of a stepladder pattern on gel electrophoresis and TUNEL staining, which are both associated with the detection of apoptotic cells. These techniques help identify the fragmented DNA and cellular components present in apoptotic bodies.

 

 

Lane B – showing apoptosis as a stepladder pattern on gel electrophoresis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apoptotic bodies, formed during the process of apoptosis, comprise cytoplasm, nuclear fragments, and organelles of the dying cell.

questions.text: Which of the following tissues is most radiosensitive? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Testis

 

Radiosensitivity refers to the susceptibility of tissues or cells to the harmful effects of radiation. The testis, particularly the germ cells within the testis, are highly radiosensitive because they have a high rate of cell division and less differentiation. Gonads, in general, are among the most radiosensitive tissues in the body. This is why testis is the correct answer.

 

Although bone is mentioned, it is not specified whether it refers to bone marrow or bone tissue. Bone marrow is indeed highly radiosensitive, but when only "bone" is mentioned, it generally refers to the harder, more resistant bone tissue rather than the marrow. Hence, in the presence of the option "testis," which is clearly highly radiosensitive, the testis is the more appropriate choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscle: Muscle tissues are relatively radioresistant because they consist of mature, differentiated cells that do not divide frequently.

 

Option B. Nerve: Nerve cells are also radioresistant due to their low mitotic activity and high differentiation, making them less susceptible to radiation damage.

 

Option C. Bone: As explained, "bone" generally refers to the solid bone tissue, which is not as radiosensitive as bone marrow. The ambiguity in the term "bone" makes it a less clear choice compared to "testis."

 

Educational Objective:

 

The testis is highly radiosensitive due to the high rate of cell division in germ cells, making it more susceptible to radiation compared to other tissues listed.

choices.text: Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice

questions.text: Which statement is incorrect about the pathology shown?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice

 

The given X-ray shows eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins with soap bubble appearance indicative of Giant cell tumour (GCT). Treatment of GCT includes Curettage or Excision with bone grafting.

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • Histology: Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue. The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of giant cells - a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumor from other tumors that may contain giant cells.

 

Clinical Features

 

  • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling.
  • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases.
  • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.

 

Radiological Features

 

  • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance.

 

Treatment

 

  • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
  • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Educational Objective

 

Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) of bone typically manifests as an eccentric lytic lesion in the epiphyseal region of long bones with distinct margins. The mainstay of treatment for GCT is surgical intervention, either through curettage or excision followed by bone grafting, rather than chemotherapy. This surgical approach helps ensure complete removal of the tumor and helps prevent recurrence.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of TTP? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thrombosis

 

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is a life-threatening condition caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of the ADAMTS13 enzyme, which leads to widespread platelet aggregation and microvascular occlusions. The classic pentad of TTP includes:

 

1. Thrombocytopenia – Due to platelet consumption in small vessel thrombi.

 

2. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia – Formation of schistocytes due to red blood cell destruction in small vessels.

 

 

3. Neurological symptoms – Ranging from confusion, headaches, and seizures to strokes.

 

4. Renal dysfunction – Present in some cases due to microvascular damage.

 

5. Fever – A non-specific symptom due to systemic inflammation.

 

While platelet-rich thrombi are characteristic of TTP, clinical thrombosis (macrovascular thrombosis like DVT or pulmonary embolism) is not a typical feature. The pathogenesis involves microvascular platelet thrombi rather than large-vessel thrombosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The classical pentad of TTP:

 

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Renal failure
  • Fever
  • Neurological manifestations

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complains of bone pain for 4 months. Her ALP levels are elevated, but serum calcium and phosphorus levels are normal, and X-ray of the patient is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paget's Disease

 

Paget's disease of bone is a chronic disorder that can result in enlarged and weakening of bones. The most commonly affected areas include the pelvis, skull, spine, and legs. In Paget's disease, the process of bone remodeling is disrupted, leading to an imbalance between the breakdown and formation of bone tissue. This results in the formation of structurally abnormal bone, which can cause pain, deformities, and an increased risk of fractures.

 

In this case, the patient presents with bone pain, elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels, and normal serum calcium and phosphorus levels, which are characteristic findings of Paget's disease. The X-ray showing multiple small spots and thickening of the calvarium is also typical of Paget's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that typically affects younger individuals and presents with localized bone pain and swelling. It is associated with elevated ALP but usually involves more aggressive bone destruction and periosteal reaction on imaging.

 

Option C. Ewing's sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that commonly affects children and adolescents. It presents with pain and swelling and is associated with a characteristic "onion skin" appearance on X-ray. The patient's age and the X-ray findings do not support this diagnosis.

 

Option D. Osteochondroma: Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor that usually presents as a painless, palpable mass near the ends of long bones in adolescents and young adults. It does not typically present with elevated ALP or the described X-ray findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paget's disease of bone is characterized by bone pain, elevated alkaline phosphatase levels, and normal serum calcium and phosphorus levels, with characteristic X-ray findings such as thickening of the calvarium

choices.text: Fanconi syndrome presents with RTA 2
Bicarbonaturia is a feature of RTA 2
RTA 4 is associated with hypokalemia
RTA 4 is due to aldosterone resistance

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement about Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA): (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) RTA 4 is associated with hypokalemia

 

Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA) refers to a group of disorders characterized by defective renal acid-base regulation, leading to a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. The main types of RTA include:

 

  • RTA Type 1 (Distal RTA): Characterized by a defect in the distal tubule's ability to secrete hydrogen ions, leading to acidosis and hypokalemia.
  • RTA Type 2 (Proximal RTA): Involves a defect in bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule, resulting in bicarbonaturia. Fanconi syndrome, a condition involving generalized proximal tubular dysfunction, often presents with RTA Type 2.
  • RTA Type 4 (Hyperkalemic RTA): This type is associated with hypoaldosteronism or aldosterone resistance, leading to impaired potassium excretion and hyperkalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fanconi syndrome presents with RTA 2: Correct. Fanconi syndrome often involves proximal RTA (Type 2), with features such as aminoaciduria, phosphaturia, glycosuria, and bicarbonaturia.

 

Option B. Bicarbonaturia is a feature of RTA 2: Correct. Due to defective bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule, bicarbonaturia is a hallmark of Type 2 RTA.

 

Option D. RTA 4 is due to aldosterone resistance: Correct. Type 4 RTA is commonly due to aldosterone deficiency or resistance, leading to hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RTA Type 4 is characterized by hyperkalemia due to aldosterone deficiency or resistance. The incorrect statement is that RTA Type 4 is associated with hypokalemia, which contradicts the typical presentation of hyperkalemia in this type of RTA.

choices.text: Block release of acetylcholine from presynaptic terminal

questions.text: The mechanism of action of botulinum toxin is? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Block release of acetylcholine from presynaptic terminal

 

Explanation:

 

Botulinum toxin works by inhibiting the exocytosis of acetylcholine from presynaptic nerve terminals. In normal neurotransmission, acetylcholine is stored in vesicles in the presynaptic neuron and released when an action potential arrives. 

 

Botulinum toxin prevents the release of acetylcholine into the synaptic cleft, effectively blocking neuromuscular transmission and causing flaccid paralysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Block postsynaptic receptors of acetylcholine:  Incorrect. Botulinum toxin doesn't affect postsynaptic receptors. Drugs that block postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors include anticholinergic agents like atropine (for muscarinic receptors) or agents like curare (for nicotinic receptors).

 

Option B. Inhibit reuptake of acetylcholine: Incorrect. Unlike noradrenaline or serotonin, acetylcholine's action is not terminated by reuptake into the presynaptic neuron. Instead, it is hydrolyzed by acetylcholinesterase in the synaptic cleft. 

 

Option D. Inhibit acetylcholinesterase: Incorrect. Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (like physostigmine, neostigmine, or pyridostigmine) increase acetylcholine levels by preventing its breakdown, resulting in enhanced cholinergic transmission. This mechanism is opposite to botulinum toxin's effect, which decreases cholinergic transmission.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acetyl choline [Ach]

 

 

→Rate limiting step is: Uptake of choline

↓Parasympathetic activity

1. Hemicholinium

2. Vesamicol

3. Botulinum toxin

Ach Esterase Inhibitor→↑Parasympathetic activity

4. Physostigmine

questions.text: 1-month-old baby came with complaints of projectile vomiting with an olive-shaped mass. X-ray abdomen was done. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pyloric stenosis

 

Pyloric stenosis is a condition commonly seen in infants where there is hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to a narrowing of the pyloric canal. This condition presents with projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeding, typically around the age of 3 to 6 weeks. The physical finding of an "olive-shaped" mass in the abdomen is characteristic of this condition, which represents the enlarged pyloric muscle.

 

The X-ray findings in pyloric stenosis often show a single bubble sign due to gastric distension without further passage of air into the intestines. This is because the pyloric canal is obstructed, preventing stomach contents from moving into the duodenum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intestinal obstruction: This term is more general and can refer to various types of obstructions within the gastrointestinal tract. In the context of an infant with projectile vomiting and an olive-shaped mass, this is not specific enough and does not pinpoint the pyloric obstruction characteristic of pyloric stenosis.

 

Option C. Duodenal atresia: Duodenal atresia is characterized by a "double bubble" sign on X-ray, which is not present in this case. This condition leads to bilious vomiting due to a congenital closure or absence of the duodenal lumen, distinguishing it from pyloric stenosis, which presents with non-bilious vomiting.

 

 

Option D. Jejunal atresia: Jejunal atresia would show a "triple bubble" sign on imaging, which indicates obstruction beyond the duodenum in the jejunum. This would also present with bilious vomiting, unlike the non-bilious vomiting seen in pyloric stenosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyloric stenosis is characterized by projectile non-bilious vomiting, the presence of an olive-shaped abdominal mass, and a single bubble sign on X-ray. It is due to hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction.

choices.text: Hormone sensitive lipase and lipoprotein lipase both increased
Hormone sensitive lipase increased & lipoprotein lipase decreased
Lipoprotein lipase increased & hormone sensitive lipase decreased
Lipoprotein lipase and hormone sensitive lipase both decreased

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with diabetes has high increased LDL and VLDL because of (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hormone sensitive lipase increased & lipoprotein lipase decreased


In diabetes, there is either a deficiency of insulin or insulin resistance. Insulin normally inhibits hormone sensitive lipase (HSL) and activates lipoprotein lipase (LPL). When insulin is deficient or not working properly, HSL activity increases while LPL activity decreases. HSL breaks down stored triglycerides in adipose tissue, releasing fatty acids into circulation. Increased HSL activity leads to more triglycerides being broken down. Meanwhile, decreased LPL activity reduces the clearance of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins from the bloodstream. This combined effect results in elevated levels of VLDL and subsequently LDL in diabetic patients.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Hormone sensitive lipase and lipoprotein lipase both increased: This is incorrect because in diabetes, these two enzymes are regulated in opposite directions. While HSL is increased, LPL is decreased due to the lack of insulin's regulatory effect.

 

Option C. Lipoprotein lipase increased & hormone sensitive lipase decreased: This is the opposite of what occurs in diabetes. This pattern would be seen in a fed state with normal insulin action, not in diabetes.

 

Option D. Lipoprotein lipase and hormone sensitive lipase both decreased: This is incorrect because in diabetes, HSL is increased, not decreased. While LPL is indeed decreased in diabetes, both enzymes are not decreased.

 

Educational Objective: 


Diabetes, hormone sensitive lipase (HSL) activity is increased while lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity is decreased due to insulin deficiency or resistance, leading to elevated levels of VLDL and LDL.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with recurrent pulmonary infections and bulky greasy stools. Quantitative estimation of the stool fat was more than 10g/day. Which of the following will be seen in this child? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Distal intestinal obstruction

 

The child's presentation of recurrent pulmonary infections and steatorrhea (bulky, greasy stools) is indicative of cystic fibrosis (CF). CF is a genetic disorder that affects the lungs and digestive system, leading to severe respiratory infections and malabsorption of nutrients.

 

In CF, thick mucus secretions can lead to blockages in various parts of the body. One of the common gastrointestinal complications is distal intestinal obstruction syndrome (DIOS), where thickened stool causes obstruction in the distal part of the small intestine. This condition is seen more frequently in older children and adults with CF, especially after the introduction of pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy (PERT).

 

The treatment of choice for distal intestinal obstruction syndrome (DIOS), which primarily involves the use of laxatives like PEG (Polyethylene glycol) is effective because it works by osmotically drawing water into the intestine, which helps to soften the stool and promote bowel movements, thereby alleviating the obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protein losing enteropathy: This condition can occur in CF, but it is more common in the infantile period or up to 2 years of age due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. It is not a primary concern in a 10-year-old child with CF presenting with the given symptoms.

 

Option C. Hypernatremia: Hypernatremia is not typically seen in CF. Instead, CF patients often exhibit hyponatremia, hypochloremia, and metabolic alkalosis due to excessive chloride loss through sweat. This electrolyte imbalance is characteristic of CF.

 

Option D. Rectal prolapse occurs after treatment: Rectal prolapse was historically a common manifestation of untreated CF in young children. However, with effective treatment, including pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy, rectal prolapse is now rare and does not usually occur after treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In children with cystic fibrosis, recurrent pulmonary infections and steatorrhea are common, and one of the significant gastrointestinal complications is distal intestinal obstruction syndrome (DIOS). This condition should be considered in CF patients presenting with symptoms of intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: A patient presented with ptosis which gets worsened by evening. He was diagnosed to be a case of myasthenia gravis. What is the preferred treatment of this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyridostigmine

 

Pyridostigmine is the preferred initial treatment for myasthenia gravis. It is effective in improving muscle strength by inhibiting the breakdown of acetylcholine, thereby increasing its availability at the neuromuscular junction. Other options like plasma exchange and cyclosporine are typically reserved for more severe cases or when standard treatments fail. Physostigmine is not commonly used for myasthenia gravis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plasma Exchange: This is used in myasthenia gravis, particularly in cases of myasthenic crisis or before surgery. It's an acute treatment method rather than a long-term management strategy.

 

Option B. Cyclosporine: This is an immunosuppressant used in the treatment of myasthenia gravis, usually in cases where patients do not respond to first-line treatments or as an adjunct therapy.

 

Option D. Physostigmine: Unlike pyridostigmine, physostigmine is not commonly used for myasthenia gravis because of its central adverse effects. It is a lipid soluble cholinesterase inhibitor and is mainly used in atropine poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor and is the mainstay of treatment for myasthenia gravis. It helps increase the levels of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, thereby improving muscle strength.

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis of a 35-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and multiple episodes of hematuria and loin pain, whose elder brother passed away due to stroke at the age of 40 and whose ultrasound abdomen is shown below? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

 

  • The clinical scenario and the ultrasound image provided suggest the diagnosis of Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD).
  • ADPKD is an inherited disorder characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys. Over time, these cysts can enlarge and decrease the functioning of the kidneys, leading to kidney failure.
  • Besides renal symptoms, patients with ADPKD can have other complications, such as cerebral aneurysms (which can rupture leading to strokes), liver cysts, and cardiac valvular diseases.
  • The combination of multiple episodes of hematuria, hypertension, familial history, and the ultrasound findings make this diagnosis the most likely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal cell carcinoma: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common type of kidney cancer in adults. It originates from the proximal convoluted tubule of the nephron. It may present with hematuria, pain in the flank or loin area, and a palpable abdominal mass. However, the familial context, with the brother's early death from a stroke, doesn't typically fit with the presentation of RCC. RCC occurs in an elderly age group.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis of the kidney: Tuberculosis (TB) can affect the kidneys, usually as a secondary site from pulmonary TB. This can lead to a chronic inflammatory response. Kidney TB might present with sterile pyuria (white blood cells in urine without bacterial growth), hematuria, and even systemic symptoms of TB like fever, weight loss, and night sweats. The clinical scenario provided doesn't specifically lean toward this diagnosis.

 

Option D. Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD): ARPKD is another inherited form of polycystic kidney disease. However, it's different from ADPKD in that it presents much earlier, usually in childhood or infancy. Symptoms in ARPKD are typically severe and can include kidney failure and liver problems at a young age.

 

  • Given the combination of clinical symptoms, family history, and ultrasound findings, the most probable diagnosis in this scenario is option B, Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) is an inherited disorder characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys, leading to kidney failure, hypertension, and a higher risk of cerebral aneurysms, making it crucial to consider family history and typical ultrasound findings in the diagnosis.

questions.text: In a gunshot case, blackening is noted surrounding a firearm entry wound. Blackening occurs mainly due to: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D. Black smoke particles

 

Blackening around the entry wound is primarily due to the deposition of smoke and soot produced from the burning propellant (gunpowder). This is most notable at close range and creates a dark mark surrounding the entry site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heat Fire Effect : This involves the heat generated by the discharge of a firearm. It can cause singeing of the hair and possibly burning of the skin around the wound, but it does not usually cause blackening.

 

Option B. Muzzle of Firearm Weapon : This refers to the end of the gun barrel. While the muzzle is close to the skin, it may deposit soot and cause burns, but it is not itself a cause of blackening. It's more about proximity effects.

 

Option C. Unburnt Gunpowder Particles : When a gun is fired, unburnt particles of gunpowder can exit the muzzle along with the bullet. These particles can cause stippling or tattooing around the wound, which is not the same as blackening but related to small abrasions on the skin.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The presence of blackening, soot, and unburnt gunpowder at a gunshot entry wound provides crucial information about the distance and angle of the shot.

questions.text: All blood products are separated by Centrifugation except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum albumin

 

Most blood components are separated using centrifugation, which involves different speeds:

 

  1. Low-speed centrifugation:
    • Separates Packed RBCs from platelet-rich plasma (PRP).
  2. High-speed centrifugation:
    • Separates platelets from plasma.
    • Plasma is further processed into Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP).
  3. Cryoprecipitate Preparation:
    • FFP is thawed at 1-6°C, allowing cryoprecipitate to form, which contains Factor VIII, fibrinogen, vWF, and Factor XIII.

 

Thus, platelets, RBCs and cryoprecipitate are all separated using centrifugation.

 

Serum albumin, however, is obtained through a process called fractionation, not centrifugation. This involves:

 

  • Cold ethanol precipitation (Cohn’s method)
  • Ultrafiltration and chromatography techniques

 

Educational Objective:

 

Centrifugation is used to separate RBCs, platelets, and plasma-derived components like cryoprecipitate. Serum albumin, however, is obtained through fractionation, making it the correct answer.

questions.text: A 32-year-old married woman who came for the evaluation of infertility was found to have a septum in her uterine cavity. What would be the appropriate management of this case? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hysteroscopy and septoplasty

 

Explanation:

 

 Hysteroscopy and septoplasty:

 

  • Uterine septum is a Mullerian anomaly where the uterine cavity is completely or partially separated by a septum. This can lead to infertility, recurrent abortions, preterm labor, fetal growth restriction, malpresentations, and retained placenta.
  • The diagnosis of a uterine septum can be confirmed through hysterosalpingography (HSG), 3D ultrasound, MRI, or hysteroscopy. Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for both diagnosis and treatment.
  • Hysteroscopic resection (septoplasty) is the appropriate management as it involves minimally invasive surgery to remove the septum, which improves reproductive outcomes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy, the removal of the uterus, is not an appropriate management for a uterine septum in a woman desiring fertility. This would completely eliminate her ability to conceive and carry a pregnancy.

 

Option B. Laparoscopy and metroplasty: While laparoscopy can be used to visualize the external uterine anatomy, metroplasty (surgical correction of the uterus) is better performed via hysteroscopy for a uterine septum. Laparoscopy is more invasive and not the first-line approach for this condition.

 

Option D. Laparotomy and metroplasty: Laparotomy is an open surgical procedure that involves a larger incision in the abdomen. This approach is unnecessarily invasive for the correction of a uterine septum, which can be effectively managed with a less invasive hysteroscopic approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate management of a uterine septum, especially in a woman seeking fertility, is hysteroscopic resection (septoplasty), which involves minimally invasive surgery to remove the septum and improve reproductive outcomes.

 

Ref: Page no 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: A - Glucose, B - PAH, C - Bicarbonate and D - Inulin
A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D - PAH
A - PAH, B - Inulin, C - Glucose and D - Bicarbonate
A - Inulin, B - Glucose, C - Bicarbonate and D – PAH

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair of substances with their renal clearance from the graph given below? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D – PAH

 

The correctly matched pair of substances and their renal clearance is option B.

 

 

The concentration of the substance changes as it passes through the tubules. Removing the substance from the filtrate is k/a tubular reabsorption and adding more of the substance to the filtrate is k/a tubular secretion.

 

Amount of the substance finally excreted = Amount Filtered + Secreted - Reabsorbed

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the renal handling of different substances such as PAH, inulin, bicarbonate, and glucose is crucial for assessing kidney function and diagnosing various renal disorders. Each substance's behavior in the nephron informs clinicians about different aspects of renal physiology, such as filtration rate and tubular function.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the management of diabetes is associated with unexplained diarrhea? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metformin

 

Metformin is a biguanide used as a first-line treatment for type 2 diabetes mellitus. One of the most common and significant side effects of metformin is gastrointestinal disturbances, particularly diarrhea. This side effect is due to the drug’s effect on the gastrointestinal tract, which can cause alterations in bowel habits, including watery diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pioglitazone: This drug is a thiazolidinedione and is not typically associated with diarrhea. Its side effects include fluid retention, weight gain, and an increased risk of bladder cancer.

 

Option B. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. While it can cause gastrointestinal side effects, it is more commonly associated with symptoms like indigestion, nausea, and bloating rather than diarrhea.

 

Option C. Glimepiride: Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea and is generally not associated with diarrhea. Its side effects typically include hypoglycemia and weight gain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metformin is commonly associated with unexplained diarrhea as a side effect, making it important for healthcare providers to monitor patients for this gastrointestinal disturbance when prescribing the medication.
