questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with abdominal pain, vomiting, oliguria, and periorbital puffiness following chemotherapy. Investigations reveal hyperuricemia and hyperkalemia. What is the next best step in the management of this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydration

 

The clinical scenario and the laboratory investigations are suggestive of tumor lysis syndrome. Aggressive hydration is the next best step in the management of this condition.

 

  • Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) can occur after chemotherapy due to release of intracellular components.
  • Increased uric acid levels cause hyperuricemia, while release of potassium and phosphate leads to hyperkalemia and hyperphosphatemia.
  • Hyperphosphatemia leads to reciprocal depression of serum calcium causing hypocalcemia.
  • TLS can result in renal failure due to deposition of uric acid crystals, calcium phosphate, and hyperphosphatemia.
  • Signs and symptoms of TLS include abdominal pain, dysuria, oliguria, flank pain, anorexia, vomiting, cramps, seizures, altered mental status, tetany, weakness, and paralysis.
  • The Cairo-Bishop criteria are used to assess the severity of TLS.
  • Management of TLS includes measuring electrolytes and aggressive hydration before starting therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Probenecid: Probenecid inhibits the organic anion transporter in the nephron, thereby inhibiting the reabsorption of uric acid. However, it is contraindicated in TLS as it increases the risk of uric acid stones due to increased uric acid levels.

 

Option C. Allopurinol: Allopurinol and febuxostat are xanthine oxidase inhibitors that decrease uric acid synthesis and treat hyperuricemia. While they are useful in managing hyperuricemia, aggressive hydration is the first-line treatment in TLS to prevent renal failure.

 

Option D. Rasburicase: Rasburicase is an enzyme that degrades uric acid and is preferred in TLS over allopurinol for rapidly reducing uric acid levels. However, initial aggressive hydration is crucial before administering rasburicase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aggressive hydration is the first-line management for tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) to prevent renal failure and facilitate the excretion of released intracellular components.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters are included in qSOFA score? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) SBP, RR, GCS score

 

  • The Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) score is used to identify patients with suspected infection who are at greater risk for a poor outcome outside the intensive care unit.
  • The qSOFA score includes three clinical criteria:
    1. Respiratory rate (RR) ≥ 22/min: A high respiratory rate indicates respiratory distress and a higher risk of organ failure.
    2. Systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≤ 100 mmHg: Low blood pressure indicates hemodynamic instability and a higher risk of mortality.
    3. Change in mental status (GCS score): Altered mental status, measured by the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), indicates possible central nervous system dysfunction.
  • Each criterion is assigned one point, and a qSOFA score of ≥2 suggests a higher risk of adverse outcomes and increased mortality.

 

qSOFA (Quick SOFA) Criteria

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BP, RR, and CBC: This option includes blood pressure and respiratory rate, but the complete blood count (CBC) is not part of the qSOFA score.

 

Option B. Creatinine, PR, BP:  Creatinine and pulse rate (PR) are not part of the qSOFA score. Blood pressure is included, but the qSOFA score focuses on systolic blood pressure specifically.

 

Option C. RR, Body temperature, PR: Respiratory rate is part of the qSOFA score, but body temperature and pulse rate are not included.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The qSOFA score includes three clinical criteria: respiratory rate (RR) ≥ 22/min, systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≤ 100 mmHg, and altered mental status (GCS score).
  • A qSOFA score of ≥2 indicates a higher risk of poor outcomes in patients with suspected infection.

questions.text: According to antenatal care, the recommended ideal number of ANC visits should be: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 12-14

 

The recommended ideal number of antenatal care (ANC) visits is typically 12 to 14. The schedule for these visits is generally as follows:

 

  • First 7 months (up to 28 weeks): One visit per month (7 visits).
  • 8th month (29-32 weeks): Two visits in the month (2 visits).
  • 9th month (33 weeks onwards): One visit per week (4-5 visits).

 

This schedule results in a total of 13 to 14 visits during the entire pregnancy. This number ensures that both the mother and the fetus are adequately monitored throughout the pregnancy, allowing for timely identification and management of any complications.

 

Note –

 

  • Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (India): Recommends at least minimum 4 visits.
  • World Health Organization (WHO): Suggests 8 visits, referring to them as "contacts." This is to ensure a basic level of care during pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal number of antenatal care visits recommended for a normal pregnancy is 12-14 to ensure optimal monitoring and care.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presented with pruritic eczematous rash on the neck and dorsum of hands. What is the likely nutritional deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B3

 

Explanation

 

Chronic alcoholics are prone to multiple nutrient deficiencies due to malnourishment and malnutrition. The given history is compatible with a disease called Pellagra, which is due to Niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency. Pellagra is characterized by the "3 D's": Diarrhea, Dermatitis, and Dementia, and it can also lead to death, sometimes referred to as the "4 D's."

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Vitamin B1: Causes Wernicke's encephalopathy, peripheral neuropathy, and heart failure but does not match the described skin condition.

 

Option C. Vitamin D: Associated with rickets and osteomalacia, not pruritic eczematous rash.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Causes scurvy with gum bleeding and other symptoms, not the described dermatitis.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Pellagra, characterized by the "3 D's" (Diarrhea, Dermatitis, Dementia), is caused by Vitamin B3 (Niacin) deficiency and is commonly seen in chronic alcoholics.

questions.text: What is the indication of this procedure? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Keratoconus

 

The given image shows the placement of Intacs, which is done for keratoconus.

  • Keratoconus is a non-inflammatory condition of the axial cornea.
  • Pathognomonic features include central or paracentral thinning of the cornea and apical protrusion of the anterior cornea.
  • Defective vision, progressive myopia, and irregular astigmatism are common clinical features.
  • Light sensitivity and ocular irritation may also be present.
  • Clinical signs: 
    1. Scissor reflex (yawning reflex) on retinoscopy is the earliest sign.
    2. Oil droplet reflex is seen with distant direct ophthalmoscopy.
    3. Fleischer’s ring (Epithelial iron deposits) and Vogt lines (Oblique stromal striae) (Image given below) are seen on slit lamp examination.
      Note: Kayser –fleischer ring is due to deposition of the copper and is seen in Wilson disease and chalcosis.
    4. Rizzuti's sign, a bright reflection from the nasal area of the limbus when light is directed to the limbus temporal area.
    5. Munson’s sign (localized bulging of the lower lid on looking down) is positive in keratoconus. (Image given below)
  • Complications include acute hydrops due to rupture of Descemet's membrane.

 

 

Vogt’s line:

 

Vogt’s triad

 

Occurs centrally in a patient with keratoconus

  • Vertical stromal/ Descemet’s membrane lines.
  • Stress lines due to stretching and thinning.
  • Disappear with globe pressure.

 

 

  • The earliest way to detect any curvature disease of the cornea including keratoconus is topography (mapping of the point-to-point thickness of the cornea).
  • The severity of the condition is graded based on keratometry.
  • Treatment: Declining visual acuity may not be corrected by glasses due to irregular astigmatism.
    1. In early cases:
      • Contact lenses (rigid gas permeable)
      • Intacs, the intracorneal ring segments (flatten the cornea)
    2. In later stages: Penetrating keratoplasty may be required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vogt's limbal girdle: Vogt's limbal girdle is a benign, age-related condition characterized by white, chalky deposits at the limbus. It is not treated with Intacs.

 

Option C. Keratoglobus: Keratoglobus is a condition characterized by a generalized thinning and globular protrusion of the entire cornea. It is not typically treated with Intacs.

 

Option D. Corneal dystrophy: Corneal dystrophies are a group of genetic, often progressive, eye disorders in which abnormal material accumulates in the cornea. Treatment varies and does not typically involve Intacs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The placement of Intacs is an indicated treatment for keratoconus, a condition characterized by the thinning and protrusion of the cornea leading to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism.

questions.text: A scuba diver surfaces rapidly, soon experiencing joint pain, dizziness, and difficulty breathing indicating decompression sickness. Which of the following is not associated with it? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Haemodilution

 

Decompression sickness (DCS), or Caisson disease, occurs due to rapid ascent during diving, based on Henry's law. When pressure decreases rapidly, dissolved gases (particularly nitrogen) form bubbles in blood and tissues. These bubbles can cause vascular occlusions, organ damage, and various systemic manifestations including hemoconcentration—not haemodilution.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coagulopathy: Incorrect. Coagulopathy can occur in DCS due to endothelial damage from gas bubbles, causing a DIC-like picture in 2–3% of cases.

 

Option B. Hearing loss: Incorrect. Hearing loss, though rare, is a possible manifestation of DCS due to inner ear involvement.

 

Option D. Visual loss: Incorrect. Visual disturbances and loss can occur in DCS due to bubble formation affecting the visual pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decompression sickness leads to hemoconcentration (not haemodilution) and can present with joint pain ("the bends"), neurological symptoms, coagulopathy, and sensory organ dysfunction including vision and hearing loss.

questions.text: Personal monitoring of radiation is done by:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. TLD badge

 

Explanation:

 

Personal monitoring of radiation is done by a TLD badge.

 

 

  • Given to radiation personnel for its usage.
  • Personnel dosimeter.
  • Thermoluminescent
  • 3 monthly [sent for measurement in India]
  • Made up of CaSO4: Dysprosium [LiF can also be used]
  • Worn below the lead apron at the level of the chest

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collimators: Used in radiographic devices to narrow the beam of radiation to limit exposure and improve image quality, but not for monitoring radiation exposure.

 

Option C. Linear accelerator: A device primarily used in cancer treatment to deliver high-energy x-rays or electrons to the region of the patient's tumor. It is not a monitoring device.

 

Option D. Grid: Used in radiographic imaging to improve image contrast by absorbing scattered radiation, not for measuring radiation exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A TLD badge is a critical tool for radiation safety, allowing for accurate monitoring and measurement of radiation exposure over time to ensure that radiation workers do not exceed safe exposure limits. This is crucial in maintaining occupational health standards in radiologically active environments.
